advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice, change the level without changing the computer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Teleplay advert for the Teleng Colourstars<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.geocities.com/doubledragon0uk//Home.html" target="_blank">Double Dragon Retro Mess</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #16</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computing today to be ready for tomorrow"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SUPERBRAIN II ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>SuperBrain II's internal circuitry has been completely redesigned. There were four models availables, from 350 KB to 10 MB of storage capacity.<br><br> The new version offered a faster enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes ans better graphics capabilities. <br><br> Prices started at $2,495</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"MO5. Adventure built-in"<br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT MARCH 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, March 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY. (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666"> The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br> The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br> At $595 it is astonishing.<br> Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br> Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br> If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Your personnal computer for 670 F"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Happy family playing "La quête des anneaux" (Quest for the rings)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Evolutiv system : Casio's answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BYTE SHOPPER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Spring 1978 issue of Byte shopper guide</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.spies.com/~aek/orphanage.html" target="_blank">The Minicomputer Orphanage</a> website</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>A computer, which grows with your requirements</i> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Joscelyn Flores</b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
Almost ten years after having conceived the Micral, world first commercial microprocessor based computer, Andr? Thi T. Truong, joined the young Normerel Company managed by his old friend Jean Ren? Tissot.
In a short time, he designed the OPlite, first computer Normerel would produce.
The Oplite was a PC compatible system featuring some innovative concepts. The case held a dual floppy disk drive and a removable 9-inch display. Standard connectors allowed an external colour TV set, a RGB or composite monitor to be used. The case also provided room for four long expansion cards.
To reach a high level of sales, Normerel joined together with Rank Xerox. The OPlite was thus sold in the large French 'Xerox Store's network alongside Apple, Toshiba and other well-known brands.
Later, Normerel would sell several PC and AT compatible systems. They made a joint-venture with ADDX Syst?mes and formed ADDX-Normerel.
In 1989, the company which lost a lot of money, was bought by SMT-Goupil. Finally, Normerel closed its doors in July 1998, the same year as SMT.
computer.keyboard: Standard 83-key PC-type with 10 function keys and Numeric keypad
computer.media: 1 or 2 x 5.25'' 360 KB FDD - Optional HDD
computer.name: OPlite
computer.peripherals: 720 KB disk drives, 10 MB hard drive
computer.ports: RGB, video composite, SCART, FDD controller, Parallel, Serial,4 expansion slots
computer.rom: 10 KB (8 KB BIOS, 2 KB Char. Generator)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br><br> • RVB connector for a CGA monitor<br> • Composite video output<br> • SCART connector, allows to connect a standard TV set<br> • Floppy disk controller connector, used to manage the internal FDDs<br> • Parallel DB25 connector<br> • Serial DB25 connector</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 4 PC-compatible expansion slots<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> 256 KB RAM (32 x 4164)<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Intel 8088 processor<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Reset switch. Another reset swith is located next to the expansion slots<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> 8 KB BIOS ROM chip (2764)<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Motorola 6845 CRT controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> 2 KB character generator chip<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> Dual double-sided, single density 360 KB mitsubishi floppy drives.<br></blockquote>
